# Luis Guillermo Solís

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

This name uses [Spanish naming customs](/wiki/Spanish_naming_customs "Spanish
naming customs"): the first or paternal [family name](/wiki/Surname "Surname")
is _Solís_ and the second or maternal family name is _Rivera_.

Luis Guillermo Solís

**Luis Guillermo Solís Rivera** (born 25 April 1958) is a [Costa
Rican](/wiki/Costa_Rica "Costa Rica") politician who has been [President of
Costa Rica](/wiki/President_of_Costa_Rica "President of Costa Rica") since
2014. He is a member of the center-left [Citizens' Action
Party](/wiki/Citizens%27_Action_Party_\(Costa_Rica\) "Citizens' Action Party
\(Costa Rica\)") (PAC). Solís led the field in the [2014 presidential
election](/wiki/Costa_Rican_general_election,_2014 "Costa Rican general
election, 2014"), and he was effectively handed the presidency after the
runner-up in the first round, [San José](/wiki/San_Jos%C3%A9,_Costa_Rica "San
José, Costa Rica") mayor [Johnny Araya Monge](/wiki/Johnny_Araya_Monge "Johnny
Araya Monge"), ceased active campaigning. Solís has a long academic and
political career, culminating in his election as the first President of Costa
Rica to be a member of the PAC.

## Early life, education, and academic
career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Luis_Guillermo_Sol%C3%ADs&action=edit&section=1&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Early life, education, and academic career")]

Solís was born in [San José, Costa Rica](/wiki/San_Jos%C3%A9,_Costa_Rica "San
José, Costa Rica"), to Vivienne Rivera Allen, an educator, and Freddy Solís
Avendaño, an uneducated [shoemaker](/wiki/Shoemaker "Shoemaker"). Both his
parents lived in [Turrialba](/wiki/Turrialba "Turrialba"), and as such many
residents consider him Turrialban.[2] His family has Afro-Caribbean and
Chinese roots, coming from [Jamaica](/wiki/Jamaica "Jamaica") to Costa Rica in
the early 1900s.[3] Solís grew up in San Pedro de [Montes de
Oca](/wiki/Montes_de_Oca_\(canton\) "Montes de Oca \(canton\)") and
[Curridabat](/wiki/Curridabat "Curridabat"), neighborhoods of San José. He
attended Methodist High School in San José, where he was president of the
student body, before studying history at the [University of Costa
Rica](/wiki/University_of_Costa_Rica "University of Costa Rica"), where he
earned a degree with academic honors in 1979.[4] He earned a master's degree
in [Latin American Studies](/wiki/Latin_American_Studies "Latin American
Studies") at [Tulane University](/wiki/Tulane_University "Tulane University")
in [New Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans "New Orleans").[5]

Solís has held various academic and consulting positions. Between 1981 and
1987, he was an associate professor at the University of Costa Rica. In
addition, he was a [Fulbright Scholar](/wiki/Fulbright_Scholar "Fulbright
Scholar") at the [University of Michigan](/wiki/University_of_Michigan
"University of Michigan") from 1983 to 1985. During this time, Solís worked
with the [Arias](/wiki/%C3%93scar_Arias "Óscar Arias") administration and
eventually became director of the Center for Peace and Reconciliation (CPR for
its Spanish initials).[4] From 1992 to 1995, Solís worked with the [Academic
Council of the United Nations
System](/wiki/Academic_Council_of_the_United_Nations_System "Academic Council
of the United Nations System"). Starting in 1999, Solís worked for [Florida
International University](/wiki/Florida_International_University "Florida
International University") as coordinator in the Center for the Administration
of Justice and as a researcher for the Latin American and Caribbean Center,
where he analyzed political and social events in Latin America.[4]

A writer and editorial writer, Solís has published numerous essays and books
about national and international affairs. In the 1990s, he wrote for _La
República_ , a daily newspaper based in San José. His writing has been
published by Foreign Affairs Latinoamérica, Frontera Norte, Espacios and
Global Governance. His writing has focused on civil society, international
relations, and trade.[4]

## Political
beginnings[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Luis_Guillermo_Sol%C3%ADs&action=edit&section=2&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Political beginnings")]

While still at UCR, Solís joined the [National Liberation
Party](/wiki/National_Liberation_Party_\(Costa_Rica\) "National Liberation
Party \(Costa Rica\)") (PLN for its Spanish initials) in 1977.[4] Solís was an
adviser to [Óscar Arias](/wiki/%C3%93scar_Arias "Óscar Arias") in the [Foreign
Ministry](/wiki/Foreign_Ministry "Foreign Ministry"), working on the
[Esquipulas Peace Agreement](/wiki/Esquipulas_Peace_Agreement "Esquipulas
Peace Agreement") for which Arias would later win a [Nobel Peace
Prize](/wiki/Nobel_Peace_Prize "Nobel Peace Prize"). Solís served as Director
of International Relations for the PLN.[4] During [José María Figueres
Olsen](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Mar%C3%ADa_Figueres_Olsen "José María Figueres
Olsen")'s time in office, Solís was ambassador of Central American Affairs.[5]

In 2002, Solís followed Rolando González Ulloa as General Secretary of the
PLN, a position he resigned from the following year,[4] citing his
disappointment with the [Alcatel-Lucent](/wiki/Alcatel-Lucent "Alcatel-
Lucent") bribery scandal that many PLN leaders were involved in. In 2005, he
denounced the PLN for irregularities and corruption during party elections,
along with a host of former PLN members.[6] Solís went as far as to call the
PLN leadership "Napoleonic" and "anti-democratic".[4] He officially renounced
his affiliation with the party and returned to academics.

After the 2006 election, Solís' name began to come up in PAC circles,
particularly at meetings of the "ungroup," an informal gathering of PAC
officials, led by former deputy and former Vice President of the [National
University of Costa Rica](/wiki/National_University_of_Costa_Rica "National
University of Costa Rica") [Alberto Salom
Echeverría](/wiki/Alberto_Salom_Echeverr%C3%ADa "Alberto Salom
Echeverría").[7] [Ottón Solís](/wiki/Ott%C3%B3n_Sol%C3%ADs "Ottón Solís"), one
of PAC's founders and three-time presidential candidate, suggested that Luis
Guillermo Solís run as a vice presidential candidate in 2010. Luis Guillermo
Solis rejected the offer because he was working for the General Secretariat of
Ibero-America (SEGIB for its Spanish initials), and employees of SEGIB were
not allowed to participate in elections.[7]

In 2009, Luis Guillermo Solís began his official affiliation with PAC.[4] He
began attending meetings of the "ungroup" in 2010. Within the party, PAC
leader María Eugenia Venegas recognized Solís' potential and pushed for him to
be elevated within the party. Solís undertook several trips around the country
to meet with national and provincial PAC leaders.[7]

## 2014 presidential
campaign[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Luis_Guillermo_Sol%C3%ADs&action=edit&section=3&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: 2014 presidential campaign")]

Solís announced his candidacy for president on 27 November 2012. In the [PAC's
primary](/wiki/Citizens%27_Action_Party_presidential_primary,_2013 "Citizens'
Action Party presidential primary, 2013"), he ran against [Epsy Campbell
Barr](/wiki/Epsy_Campbell_Barr "Epsy Campbell Barr"), [Juan Carlos Mendoza
García](/wiki/Juan_Carlos_Mendoza_Garc%C3%ADa "Juan Carlos Mendoza García"),
and [Ronald Solís Bolaños](/wiki/Ronald_Sol%C3%ADs_Bola%C3%B1os "Ronald Solís
Bolaños"), winning with 35 percent of the vote,[4] only 110 votes more than
Juan Carlos Mendoza García.[7]

In October 2013, he chose [Helio Fallas](/wiki/Helio_Fallas "Helio Fallas")
and [Ana Helena Chacón
Echeverría](/wiki/Ana_Helena_Chac%C3%B3n_Echeverr%C3%ADa "Ana Helena Chacón
Echeverría") as his Vice-Presidential running mates.[8] Among his aims, Solís
claimed he would clean up corruption, create major investments in
infrastructure, and shore up Costa Rica's [universal health
care](/wiki/Universal_health_care "Universal health care") and [social
security](/wiki/Social_security "Social security") system.[3] He also promised
to continue initiatives to keep Costa Rica environmentally friendly.[9] He
said that he would "put the brakes" on new free trade agreements and would
begin correctly administrating current free trade agreements.[10] As such,
Solís received a tremendous amount of political support from [the country's
trade unions](/wiki/Trade_unions_in_Costa_Rica "Trade unions in Costa Rica").
[11]

On 2 February 2014, Solís won the most votes in the election with 30.95
percent. PLN candidate [Johnny Araya](/wiki/Johnny_Araya "Johnny Araya") came
second with 29.95 percent of the vote.[12] Most of Solís' support came from
the Central Valley provinces of [San José](/wiki/San_Jos%C3%A9_Province "San
José Province"), [Alajuela](/wiki/Alajuela_Province "Alajuela Province"),
[Heredia](/wiki/Heredia_Province "Heredia Province") and
[Cartago](/wiki/Cartago_Province "Cartago Province").[13]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/PAC_Plaza_Roosevelt_2.jpg/220px-
PAC_Plaza_Roosevelt_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:PAC_Plaza_Roosevelt_2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:PAC_Plaza_Roosevelt_2.jpg "Enlarge")

PAC supporters wave their traditional colors to celebrate Luis Guillermo
Solís' victory on 6 April 2014

Because no candidate exceeded 40 percent of the vote, a runoff was scheduled
for 6 April, as required by the constitution. However, on 5 March, Araya
announced that he would abandon his campaign after polls showed him far behind
Solís; one poll showed him losing by over 43 percent.[14] However, under Costa
Rican law the runoff still had to take place, and Solís won with over 77
percent of the vote, the largest margin ever recorded for a free election in
Costa Rica.[15][16][17] Unlike the first round, Solís earned a majority in
every province, including [Puntarenas](/wiki/Puntarenas_\(canton\) "Puntarenas
\(canton\)"), [Limón](/wiki/Lim%C3%B3n "Limón"), and
[Guanacaste](/wiki/Guanacaste_Province "Guanacaste Province").[18] When he
took office on 8 May, he was the first president in 66 years not to come from
the PLN or what is now the PUSC.[18]

Immediately after the election, Solís thanked Costa Rican voters. He received
congratulatory notes from world leaders, including [US Secretary of
State](/wiki/US_Secretary_of_State "US Secretary of State") [John
Kerry](/wiki/Secretary_of_State_John_Kerry "Secretary of State John Kerry"),
Ecuadoran President [Rafael Correa](/wiki/Rafael_Correa "Rafael Correa"),
Mexican President [Enrique Peña Nieto](/wiki/Enrique_Pe%C3%B1a_Nieto "Enrique
Peña Nieto"), Venezuelan President [Nicolás Maduro](/wiki/Nicol%C3%A1s_Maduro
"Nicolás Maduro"), Bolivian President [Evo Morales](/wiki/Evo_Morales "Evo
Morales"), and the spokesperson from the French Ministry of International
Affairs.[19] For his part, Araya congratulated Solís on his victory, calling
for national unity.[20]

##
Presidency[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Luis_Guillermo_Sol%C3%ADs&action=edit&section=4&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Presidency")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Luis_Guillermo_Sol%C3%ADs%2C_Costa_Rica_04.JPG/220px-
Luis_Guillermo_Sol%C3%ADs%2C_Costa_Rica_04.JPG)](/wiki/File:Luis_Guillermo_Sol%C3%ADs,_Costa_Rica_04.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Luis_Guillermo_Sol%C3%ADs,_Costa_Rica_04.JPG "Enlarge")

Solís speaking in 2014

A little over a week before taking office, in April 2014, Solís announced the
creation of his [cabinet](/wiki/Cabinet_\(government\) "Cabinet
\(government\)"). His cabinet consists of mostly PAC members or non-aligned
citizens. However, two PUSC members were also added: María del Rocío Sáenz,
[Abel Pacheco](/wiki/Abel_Pacheco "Abel Pacheco")'s former health minister,
heads the [Costa Rican Social Security
System](/wiki/Caja_Costarricense_del_Seguro_Social "Caja Costarricense del
Seguro Social") (Caja Costarricense del Seguro Social). Delia Villalobos,
another former health minister, heads the Social Protection Council (Consejo
de Seguridad).[21]

Solís took office on 8 May 2014,[22] amid festive fanfare.[23] Delegations
from more than 80 countries attended his inauguration at [La Sabana
Metropolitan Park](/wiki/La_Sabana_Metropolitan_Park "La Sabana Metropolitan
Park"), including [Prince Felipe de
Borbón](/wiki/Prince_Felipe_de_Borb%C3%B3n_y_Grecia "Prince Felipe de Borbón y
Grecia") of Spain, [Evo Morales](/wiki/Evo_Morales "Evo Morales") of
[Bolivia](/wiki/Bolivia "Bolivia"), [Rafael Correa](/wiki/Rafael_Correa
"Rafael Correa") of [Ecuador](/wiki/Ecuador "Ecuador"), and the Secretary
General of the [Organization of American
States](/wiki/Organization_of_American_States "Organization of American
States"), [José Miguel Insulza](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Miguel_Insulza "José Miguel
Insulza").[24] Solís said, in Costa Rican vernacular, that he is taking over a
"weed farm" (finca encharralada),[22] pointing out growing income inequality
and poverty, as well as a national teachers' strike.[25]

### Economic
issues[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Luis_Guillermo_Sol%C3%ADs&action=edit&section=5&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Economic issues")]

In 2014, President Solís presented a budget with an increase in spending of
19% for 2015, an increase of 0.5% for 2016 and an increase of 12% for
2017.[26] When the 2017 budget was finally proposed, it totaled US$15.9
billion. Debt payments account for one-third of that amount. Of greater
concern is the fact that a full 46% of the budget will require financing, a
step that will increase the debt owed to foreign entities.[27]

The country's credit rating was reduced by [Moody's Investors
Service](/wiki/Moody%27s_Investors_Service "Moody's Investors Service") in
early 2017 to Ba2 from Ba1, with a negative outlook on the rating. The agency
particularly cited the "rising government debt burden and persistently high
fiscal deficit, which was 5.2% of GDP in 2016". Moody's was also concerned
about the "lack of political consensus to implement measures to reduce the
fiscal deficit [which] will result in further pressure on the government's
debt ratios".[28] In late July 2017, the Costa Rica Central Bank estimated the
budget deficit at 6.1 percent of the country's GDP.[29]

A 2017 study by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
warned that reducing the foreign debt must be a very high priority for the
government. Other fiscal reforms were also recommended to moderate the budget
deficit.[30]

#### Liquidity
problems[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Luis_Guillermo_Sol%C3%ADs&action=edit&section=6&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Liquidity problems")]

In early August 2017, the President promised admitted that the country was
facing a "liquidity crisis" and promised that a higher VAT tax and higher
income tax rates were being considered by his government. Such steps are
essential, Solís told the nation, because it was facing difficulties in paying
its obligations and guaranteeing the provision of services."[31] "Despite all
the public calls and efforts we have made since the start of my administration
to contain spending and increase revenues, there is still a gap that we must
close with fresh resources," he said. The crisis was occurring in spite of
growth, low inflation and continued moderate interest rates, Solís
concluded.[32]

He explained that the Treasury will prioritize payments on the public debt
first, then salaries, and then pensions. The subsequent priorities include
transfers to institutions "according to their social urgency." All other
payments will be made only if funds are available.[33]

## Political, economic, and social
philosophy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Luis_Guillermo_Sol%C3%ADs&action=edit&section=7&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Political, economic, and social philosophy")]

The past generated two different economies: one very dynamic, modern and
generally oriented toward international markets, with limited possibilities
for new sources of employment, and the other, traditional, which created many
jobs with low pay where small and medium-sized businesses concentrated.

Luis Guillermo Solís, _[Plan Rescate,
2014-2018](http://www.tse.go.cr/pdf/varios/plan_gobierno_pac.pdf)_

Like most members of PAC, Solís identifies himself as a
[progressivist](/wiki/Progressivism "Progressivism"). His _Plan Rescate_ , or
_Rescue Plan_ , outlines his political beliefs. This plan focused on three
central issues: [anti-corruption](/wiki/Corruption "Corruption"), [economic
growth](/wiki/Economic_growth "Economic growth"), and reducing [income
inequality](/wiki/Income_inequality "Income inequality").[34]

Solís claims that economic [neoliberalism](/wiki/Neoliberalism
"Neoliberalism") has created too much income inequality for Costa Rica.[34]
Past governments have avoided collecting taxes on large companies and high-
income earners, leading to [budget deficits](/wiki/Budget_deficits "Budget
deficits") which Solís claims his administration will fix through better
enforcement.[34] Banks should not encourage exports at the expense of income
growth among the poor, according to Solís.[34] He believes that economic
liberalization has generally harmed women more than men because they have
traditionally had less access to higher-income jobs. Part of that
liberalization, he claims, included ignoring the financial and growth needs of
the agricultural industry.[35]

Solís supports environmental protections, which he believes Costa Rica has
forgotten.[9] As such, Solís believes that water must be safeguarded from
private development and mismanagement, something that has caused water
shortages in many of the country's municipalities. Solís claims that he will
prosecute violators of the Water Resources Management Bill.[34]

In addition, Solís supports increased rights for [rights for lesbians, gays,
bisexuals, and transsexuals](/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_Costa_Rica "LGBT rights in
Costa Rica"). In May 2014, he ordered that a [rainbow
flag](/wiki/Rainbow_flag_\(LGBT_movement\) "Rainbow flag \(LGBT movement\)")
be flown over the Presidential House as a show of solidarity with gays on
International Day Against Homophobia and Transphobia.[36]

Solís is a [Catholic](/wiki/Roman_Catholic "Roman Catholic").[35] As a
presidential candidate, he visited the [basilica of Our Lady of
Angels](/w/index.php?title=Basilica_of_Our_Lady_of_Angels,_Cartago&action=edit&redlink=1
"Basilica of Our Lady of Angels, Cartago \(page does not exist\)"), home to
the Costa Rican [patron saint](/wiki/Patron_saint "Patron saint") [La
Negrita](/wiki/Virgen_de_los_Angeles "Virgen de los Angeles"), a traditional
pilgrimage for many Costa Ricans and tourists.[35] He supports the [separation
of church and state](/wiki/Separation_of_church_and_state "Separation of
church and state") despite Catholicism being the country's official
religion.[37] With regard to ethical issues, he also supports [civil
unions](/wiki/Civil_unions "Civil unions"), and [in-vitro
fertilization](/wiki/In-vitro_fertilization "In-vitro fertilization").[35]

## Personal
life[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Luis_Guillermo_Sol%C3%ADs&action=edit&section=8&editintro=Template:BLP_editintro
"Edit section: Personal life")]

Solis has ten children from his previous marriage to his first wife, Nancy
Olive Worsfold Richards (1987–2006): Monica, Cristina, Beatriz, Charlie,
Carly, Jennifer, John, Carlos, Diego and Ignacio.[38][1]

Solís is not married to [Mercedes Peñas
Domingo](/wiki/Mercedes_Pe%C3%B1as_Domingo "Mercedes Peñas Domingo"), but she
is altogether considered the [First Lady of Costa
Rica](/wiki/First_Lady_of_Costa_Rica "First Lady of Costa Rica").[39] He and
Peñas, who began dating in 2006, have one daughter, Inés.[1][38] Peñas said
that she hopes to be active as an adviser to Solís, who called her "[Jiminy
Cricket](/wiki/Jiminy_Cricket "Jiminy Cricket")."[39] Saying that some of her
duties as [First Lady](/wiki/First_Lady "First Lady") are
[machista](/wiki/Machismo "Machismo"), she will nevertheless greet dignitaries
and perform other obligations.[39] In addition to public service and
academics, Solís enjoys farming.[35]
